prompt.preamble: We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences. In this activity, we're going to be looking at different strings of text and you'll be deciding if they look like they could be an email address or not. For example, most people would agree that "username@domain.com" looks like an email address, while "n12z5lFEN4" does not. However, the rules for what can be an email address can be very unusual, so what we're really interested in is your intuition on what an email address could look like. Tip: in an email such as username@cs.stanford.edu, "username" is called the local-part of the email, while "cs.stanford.edu" is the domain. Furthermore, "cs" is a subdomain, and "edu" is a top-level domain.
prompt.task_description: your intuition of what is or is not possible for an email address
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of email addresses, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your email preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following strings look like reasonably well-formatted email addresses or not: "yes" if they do, "no" if they don't.

conversation_history.message: Can you describe what kind of special characters, if any, you believe should be allowed in an email address and where they should be placed?
dots and underscores should be allowed in both local part and domain
What are your thoughts on the length of an email address? Is there a minimum or maximum number of characters you believe an email address should have?
at least 5 characters
What are your thoughts on the use of numbers in an email address? Should they be allowed in both the local part and the domain, and if so, are there any restrictions on their placement or quantity?
no limit to numbers which should be allowed everywhere

What are your thoughts on the use of capital letters in an email address? Should they be allowed in both the local part and the domain, and if so, are there any restrictions on their placement or quantity?
they should be allowed everywhere with no limit
What are your thoughts on the use of special characters like hyphens or plus signs in an email address? Should they be allowed, and if so, where should they be placed?
hyphens and pluses should be allowed in both places

What are your thoughts on the use of non-alphanumeric characters, such as exclamation marks, dollar signs, or percent signs in an email address? Should they be allowed, and if so, where should they be placed?
they shouldn't be allowed

What are your thoughts on the use of periods or dots in the email address? Should there be any restrictions on their placement, such as not being allowed at the start or end of the email address, or not being allowed consecutively (e.g., "john..doe@example.com")?
yes to all the mentioned restrictions

What are your thoughts on the use of subdomains in an email address? For example, should an email address like john.doe@sales.example.com be considered valid? If so, are there any restrictions on their use or placement?
no restriction

What are your thoughts on the use of international characters in an email address, such as accents, umlauts, or characters from non-Latin alphabets? Should they be allowed, and if so, where should they be placed?
all ascii characters should be allowed

What are your thoughts on the use of multiple '@' symbols in an email address? For example, should an email address like john.doe@sales@example.com be considered valid? If not, what restrictions should be placed on the use of '@' symbols?
only one @ to separate local and domain

What are your thoughts on the use of consecutive special characters, such as hyphens, underscores, or plus signs, in an email address? For example, should an email address like john--doe@example.com or john__doe@example.com be considered valid? If not, what restrictions should be placed on the use of consecutive special characters?
no restriction
What are your thoughts on the use of spaces in an email address? Should they be allowed, and if so, where should they be placed?
they shouldn't be allowed

What are your thoughts on the use of special characters like the underscore (_) in the domain part of the email address? For example, should an email address like john.doe@example_com be considered valid? If not, what restrictions should be placed on the use of such special characters in the domain part?
the domain needs to have a point at the end in any situation to be considered valid

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn what rules a user believes to be a valid email address format must adhere to (e.g. for developing a regex format checker).

Previous questions:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative open-ended question that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Make sure your question addresses different aspects of the regex than the questions that have already been asked. At the same time however, the question should be bite-sized, and not ask for too much at once. Phrase your question in a way that is understandable to non-expert humans; do not use any jargon without explanation. Generate the open-ended question and nothing else:
